natural problem: Find all real values of $x$ that satisfy $\frac{x(x+1)}{(x-4)^2} \ge 12.$ (Give your answer in interval notation.)
natural solution: Because $(x-4)^2$ is always nonnegative, we can safety multiply both sides of the inequality by $(x-4)^2$ without changing the direction of the inequality, with the caveat that we cannot have $x = 4$: \[\begin{aligned} x(x+1) &\ge 12(x-4)^2 \\ 0 &\ge 11x^2 - 97x + 192.

\end{aligned}\]This quadratic factors as \[0 \ge (x-3)(11x-64),\]which holds if and only if $3 \le x \le \frac{64}{11}.$ However, since $x \neq 4,$ the solutions to the original inequality are given by \[x \in \boxed{[3, 4) \cup \left(4, \frac{64}{11}\right]}\,.\]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "(x*(x+1))/((x-4)^(2)) \<ge> 12"
shows  "x \<in> {x. 3 \<le> x \<and> x < 4} \<union> {x. 4 < x \<and> x < 64/11}"
a_0.formal solution:

 ### Proof
 Because $(x-4)^2$ is always nonnegative, we can safety multiply both sides of the inequality by $(x-4)^2$ without changing the direction of the inequality, with the caveat that we cannot have $x = 4$: \[\begin{aligned} x(x+1) &\ge 12(x-4)^2 \\ 0 &\ge 11x^2 - 97x + 192.
 \end{aligned}\]This quadratic factors as \[0 \ge (x-3)(11x-64),\]which holds if and only if $3 \le x \le \frac{64}{11}.$ However, since $x \neq 4,$ the solutions to the original inequality are given by \[x \in \boxed{[3, 4) \cup \left(4, \frac{64}{11}\right]}\,.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "(x*(x+1))/((x-4)^(2)) \<ge> 12"
shows  "x \<in> {x. 3 \<le> x \<and> x < 4} \<union> {x. 4 < x \<and> x < 64/11}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the range of values for $x$ such that the inequality $\frac{x*(x+1)}{(x-4)^2} \geq 12$ is satisfied. The solution set is $x \in [3, 4) \cup (4, \frac{64}{11})$.

assumes h0 : "(x * (x + 1)) / ((x - 4) powr 2) \<ge> 12"
shows  "(x \<in> {3..4}) \<or> (x \<in> {4<..64/11})"
